nodes.text: Contact comfort provided by a soft, warm, tactile mother surrogate is the primary variable driving infant macaque affectional bonding, more so than nursing or food-related reinforcement
Contact comfort is an overwhelming and primary affectional variable in infant macaques and can account for preference and security-seeking behavior toward a mother surrogate

Constructed a cloth-covered wooden surrogate mother with sponge rubber and radiant heat to provide soft, warm contact comfort (engineering design emphasized maintenance efficiency and continuous availability)

Dual mother-surrogate experimental design: infants exposed to a cloth mother and a wire mother in attached cubicles; feeding was assigned such that in half the subjects the cloth mother lactated and in half the wire mother lactated; time on each surrogate was automatically recorded and multiple behavioral tests were run
Result: Infants spent substantially more time on the cloth mother than the wire mother regardless of which surrogate provided milk, demonstrating preference for contact comfort over nursing
Evidence: Differential preference for the cloth mother persisted throughout 165 consecutive days of testing, showing long-term stability of the contact-comfort bond

Result in fear tests and open-field tests: when presented with fear-producing stimuli or placed in a strange environment the infants consistently sought the cloth mother as a haven of safety regardless of nursing condition

Result from control comparisons: infants reared only with a wire mother versus only with a cloth mother showed no differences in milk intake or weight gain, but wire-mother infants had softer stools suggestive of psychosomatic effects, indicating wire mother was biologically adequate but psychologically inept

Result from retention and puzzle tests: affectional responsiveness to the cloth mother showed little or no waning over a 185-day retention period and infants worked to regain access to the mother surrogate post-separation, indicating strong retention and resistance to extinction

Result from late-adoption controls: monkeys raised without surrogates until 250 days initially showed fear or indifference but within about 10 days developed strong contact with the cloth mother, though peak contact time was lower than animals mothered from birth

Claim other tactile and sensorimotor variables (postural support, rocking motion, clinging ability), as well as sounds and visual features like the maternal face, may also contribute to affectional development and are worth systematic study

Result: Presence of the cloth mother behind a transparent barrier (Plexiglas) reduced emotionality compared with absence of the mother, showing that mere presence and visual/olfactory cues provide security even when physical contact is denied

Claim nursing and feeding per se are insufficient to account for the formation and persistence of affectional bonds; the principal function of nursing may be to provide frequent intimate body contact rather than to serve as the conditioned reinforcer of love

Conclusion and applied implication: findings suggest practical implications for child-rearing (e.g., contact provision may substitute for nursing in some contexts) and motivate further study of human infant care practices

Assumption: neonatal and infant macaque perceptual, motor, and affectional developmental sequences are sufficiently similar to human infants to justify using macaques as a model for basic affectional variables
Conclusion: Affectional bonds formed on the basis of contact comfort are highly resistant to extinction, long-lasting, and can be retained with relatively infrequent contact reinforcement
